metadata.titleEn: Qilian Mountains integrated observatory network: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network (Large aperture scintillometer of Sidaoqiao Superstation, 2021)
metadata.description:
This dataset contains the flux measurements from the large aperture scintillometer (LAS) at Sidaoqiao Superstation in the Heihe integrated observatory network from January 1 to December 31 in 2021. There were BLS900 and BLS450 at Sidaoqiao Superstation. The north towers were set up with these instruments’ receivers and the south towers were transmitters. The site (north: 101.137° E, 42.008° N; south: 101.131° E, 41.987 N) was located in Ejinaqi, Inner Mongolia. The underlying surfaces between the two towers were tamarisk, populus, bare land and farmland. The elevation is 873 m. The effective height of the LAS was 25.5 m, and the path length was 2350 m. The data were sampled 1 minute.
The raw data acquired at 1 min intervals were processed and quality controlled. The data were subsequently averaged over 30 min periods, in which sensible heat flux was iteratively calculated by combining Cn2 with meteorological data according to the Monin-Obukhov similarity theory. The main quality control steps were as follows: (1) The data were rejected when Cn2 exceeded the saturated criterion (BLS900&BLS450：Cn2>7.25E-14). (2) The data were rejected when the demodulation signal was small (BLS900&BLS450：Average X Intensity<1000). (3) The data were rejected when collected during precipitation. (4) The data were rejected if collected at night when weak turbulence occurred (u* was less than 0.1 m/s). In the iteration process, the universal functions of Thiermann and Grassl (1992) were selected for BLS900 and BLS450. Detailed can refer to Liu et al. (2011, 2013). Due to instrument adjustment and inadequate power supply, the date of missing data for the large aperture scintillator is: 2021.03.15-2021.03.18；2021.9.12-2021.9.18.
Several instructions were included with the released data. (1) The las data are firstly from BLS900, followed by BLS450, and finally the final missing data was marked with-6999. (2) The dataset contained the following variables: Date/time (yyyy/m/d h:mm), the structural parameter of the air refractive index (Cn2, m-2/3), and the sensible heat flux (H, W/m^2). In this dataset, a time of 0:30 corresponds to the average data for the period between 0:00 and 0:30, and the data were stored in *.xlsx format. 
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2018) (for sites information), Liu et al. (2011) (for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Definition.Question: What does 'large aperture scintillometer' mean in the context of data collection methods for observing atmospheric conditions?
Definition.Answer: A large aperture scintillometer is an instrument used for measuring fluxes of heat and momentum in the atmosphere. It consists of a transmitter and a receiver set at a certain distance apart, which measures the refractive index structure parameter of the air. This parameter is used to calculate sensible heat flux based on atmospheric conditions. In the context of the dataset, BLS450 and BLS900 are models of large aperture scintillometers used for flux measurements.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'quality control' in the context of processing observational data?
Definition.Answer: Quality control in the context of processing observational data involves steps taken to ensure the accuracy and reliability of data collected from instruments. This includes removing data that may be affected by instrument saturation, weak signal intensity, precipitation events, or unstable atmospheric conditions. The process aims to ensure that the final dataset is devoid of errors and provides valid and reliable measurements for analysis.

Definition.Question: What is the 'eddy covariance system' as a data collection method in oasis-desert ecosystem studies?
Definition.Answer: The eddy covariance system is a data collection method used to measure and calculate turbulent fluxes of gases such as carbon dioxide, water vapor, and methane between the land surface and the atmosphere. It provides high-frequency, half-hourly data on these fluxes, often used in combination with other instruments like scintillometers to understand energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange dynamics in ecosystems, such as those found in oasis-desert areas.

Comparison.Question: How do the data quality control steps for the large aperture scintillometer flux observations differ from those used in eddy covariance systems within oasis–desert ecosystems?
Comparison.Answer: The large aperture scintillometer data undergo quality control steps such as removing saturated Cn2 data, weak demodulated signal intensity, data during precipitation, and weak turbulence under stable conditions. In contrast, eddy covariance systems typically focus on ensuring data continuity, removing spikes, and correcting for instrument errors and environmental factors, emphasizing different aspects due to the distinct data collection nature of each method.

Comparison.Question: How does the use of auxiliary data like vegetation and soil parameters in oasis–desert ecosystem datasets compare to their use in datasets focused solely on atmospheric flux measurements?
Comparison.Answer: In oasis–desert ecosystem datasets, auxiliary data such as vegetation and soil parameters are integral for understanding interactions between land surfaces and atmospheric processes, providing context for energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes. In datasets focused solely on atmospheric flux measurements, auxiliary data may be less emphasized, focusing more on atmospheric conditions and immediate surface flux interactions without the broader ecological context.

Interpretation.Question: How might the iterative calculation process based on the Monin-Obukhov similarity theory be applied to improve data quality and accuracy in other environmental datasets?
Interpretation.Answer: The iterative calculation process based on the Monin-Obukhov similarity theory is used to derive heat fluxes from raw scintillometer data, ensuring data accuracy and quality. This method could be applied to other environmental datasets where similar atmospheric stability conditions and turbulent flux measurements are involved, potentially enhancing the precision of observations related to heat, water vapor, or carbon exchanges in diverse ecosystems.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges might arise when implementing quality control procedures for datasets collected in arid and semi-arid regions, and how could these be mitigated?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges in implementing quality control procedures in arid and semi-arid regions include dealing with signal saturation, weak signal intensity, and data contamination from precipitation or weak turbulence. These challenges are mitigated by removing data points that exceed certain thresholds, such as high refractive index structure parameters, low signal intensity, and unstable conditions. These procedures help maintain data integrity and reliability.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways can the integration of automatic weather stations and scintillometer data contribute to a comprehensive understanding of energy and water vapor exchanges in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Interpretation.Answer: The integration of automatic weather stations and scintillometer data provides a robust dataset that includes turbulent fluxes, hydrometeorological conditions, and soil parameters. This comprehensive data collection strategy allows researchers to analyze energy and water vapor exchanges in detail, offering insights into the interactions between oasis and desert systems and supporting sustainable development and ecological stability in these regions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are involved in processing and quality controlling the data collected by large aperture scintillometers in arid regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The data collected by large aperture scintillometers undergoes a process where the raw 1-minute observation data is processed and quality controlled. This includes removing data where the refractive index structure parameter (Cn2) reaches saturation, eliminating data with weak demodulation signal intensity, excluding data during precipitation events, and discarding data with weak turbulence under stable conditions. The processing involves using the Monin-Obukhov similarity theory for iterative calculations, with stability functions selected from previous studies.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes in oasis-desert ecosystems quantitatively measured and documented?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes in oasis-desert ecosystems are measured using a combination of eddy covariance systems and scintillometers. The data is collected half-hourly and includes hydrometeorological measurements such as radiation, soil heat flux, air temperature gradients, wind speed, air pressure, and soil moisture profiles. Automatic weather stations provide additional data with a 10-minute average period. This suite of datasets helps in understanding the oasis-desert interactions and their ecological impacts.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methods are employed to ensure the accuracy and reliability of hydrometeorological data in arid and semi-arid regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To ensure the accuracy and reliability of hydrometeorological data, the data collection methods include using automatic weather stations that record data at regular intervals (e.g., 10-minute averages). The data processing involves a comprehensive quality control procedure that encompasses data collection, processing, and archiving. This includes monitoring radiation, soil heat flux, temperature profiles, wind parameters, and other relevant meteorological data to maintain data integrity.

Data quality control involves removing saturated data, weak signal intensity data, data during precipitation, and weak turbulence data under stable conditions. Iterative calculations using stability universal functions are also applied.

These instruments enable high-frequency data acquisition, which facilitates a comprehensive understanding of the energy and water vapor dynamics in oasis-desert ecosystems.
